TopicTitle: Three months after joining forces with Curse.com, this is what...

Articles.Content: <img src="https://gs1.wac.edgecastcdn.net/8019B6/data.tumblr.com/54dc6444018ead8a5015aedd95fb5822/tumblr_n9wiwxSlYb1ry6jwuo1_1280.jpg"/><br/><br/><p>Three months after joining forces with Curse.com, this is what our awesome players have accomplished.</p> Edited August 6, 2014 by sal_vager
I assume that in a moment there will be a bigger version available? This one is too teeny to read

I assume that in a moment there will be a bigger version available? This one is too teeny to read

Ditto. Not even right click open in new window helps much. Also, is that "1.528 million downloads" or "1,528 million downloads"?
Yep. Hard to read but still good info. Seems like all you hear is the "anti-Curse" rhetoric, it's good to see what's working.

Are the numbers corrected with the growing community? Having more downloads does not necessary mean more acceptance....

4 hours for confirmation by Course for some of the most established mods, well is not really what I like but, the normal players(non excessive Forum viewers) I guess just take it, because it is official.

After these 3 months I'm still sceptical.

As example what about some Steam statistics? In the Top50 selling games since launch, that is impressive

That is just my opinion and my only, as I don't want to start over a discussion about it.

What I would like to know is the relation of these 1,528 Million mod downloads and the amound of players. the average Player has how many mods?

Also it Looks like a little mistake, 1,528 Million Downloads and 1,528 projects, I can't believe it is the same by luck.

Nice numbers but I am not impressed. If the spaceport was properly redesigned the results would have been the same. Probably even better.

KerbalStuff currently has 136 mods.

Here is an infographic.


  ******
 *      *
*  136   *
*  mods  *
 *      *
  ******

   YAY

Cute.

Kerbalstuff is in Beta, is community run, and Squad won't even mention it by name. Yet it has more than 50% of the number of mods on Curse (130 on KS verses 230 on Curse) and the major mods being downloaded there are mostly on pace with download numbers. KW rocketry, for instance, is on Kerbalstuff too, and was added after it had been on Curse for a while; it already has 27k downloads with no Curse network traffic or any link from a Squad page.

No, I think Kerbalstuff is doing just fine.

I am more amused and a little offended that Squad implies that somehow the modding community is being driven by Curse, or that whats going on on Curse even represents a majority of its modding community. Spaceport wasn't the majority, Curse isn't, Kerbalstuff isn't.

Squad would do better to celebrate the modders and not the site that hosts them. Curse isn't providing content for their game, the modders are. Even those that don't use Curse.

Edited August 6, 2014 by Tiberion

I am more amused and a little offended that Squad implies that somehow the modding community is being driven by Curse, or that whats going on on Curse even represents a majority of its modding community. Spaceport wasn't the majority, Curse isn't, Kerbalstuff isn't.

Squad would do better to celebrate the modders and not the site that hosts them. Curse isn't providing content for their game, the modders are. Even those that don't use Curse.

Totally 100% agreed. A list of statistics about Curse isn't unwelcome; I'm glad it's functioning better than Space Port was. But a cute infographic feels like someone trying to sell me something I don't really care about.
Thank you modders for making such amazing mods, and for allowing us the privilege of downloading your work from where ever you choose to locate it .

I, too, thank the modding community for the great work they have created. Squad provided an excellent foundation upon which to build, and it provides the info and support to help the modders. Where Squad provides the skeleton, it's the modders who really flesh-out KSP. As KSP grows and evolves, I look forward to what the modders will accomplish.

Cute.

Kerbalstuff is in Beta, is community run, and Squad won't even mention it by name. Yet it has more than 50% of the number of mods on Curse (130 on KS verses 230 on Curse) and the major mods being downloaded there are mostly on pace with download numbers. KW rocketry, for instance, is on Kerbalstuff too, and was added after it had been on Curse for a while; it already has 27k downloads with no Curse network traffic or any link from a Squad page.

No, I think Kerbalstuff is doing just fine.

I am more amused and a little offended that Squad implies that somehow the modding community is being driven by Curse, or that whats going on on Curse even represents a majority of its modding community. Spaceport wasn't the majority, Curse isn't, Kerbalstuff isn't.

Squad would do better to celebrate the modders and not the site that hosts them. Curse isn't providing content for their game, the modders are. Even those that don't use Curse.

Agreed.

For the time and resources available to it, along with the head start curse had, I think kerbalstuff is doing excellently.

Kinda hoping we'll witness the tipping point being reached.

Totally 100% agreed. A list of statistics about Curse isn't unwelcome; I'm glad it's functioning better than Space Port was. But a cute infographic feels like someone trying to sell me something I don't really care about.

That info graphic is just cold numbers. Kerbalstuff deserves a mention too.

Tring to promote Curse like this is a bit annoying. Most of us don't even care about Curse anymore, we care about the game.
Info-graphics are overrated.

The good, the bad and the ugly

Good:

Let's not forget that Spaceport was not the most stable site at the end of its life. One can argue that at that point little or no maintenance was done (I suspect) but at the same time, I'd rather see Squad spend resources on developing the game than on maintaining Spaceport. Curse has issues, but requires zero work from Squad (I assume).

Bad:

Curse isn't liked. The disconnect is that Squad's decision to go Curse is likely along the lines of Ã¢â‚¬Å“does it require resources on our side? NO. Is it free for players? YES. Is it more stable and faster? YES. Deal!Ã¢â‚¬Â What's missing is words as Ã¢â‚¬Å“best solution.Ã¢â‚¬Â Then again their reasoning might be if the community can do it better they're more than welcome to do so. Yes, Squad doesn't advertise the other mod sites. But it doesn't actively fight them either.

The Ugly:

Aaaah the numbers. Do they have meaning? What do "before" and "after" mean? Does "before" include a release cycle followed by everyone frantically downloading new mods? But good to see that they have stats on what are the most popular downloads, and that those are being showcased.

The Verdict

Not everyone agrees with the Cursed decision. But... is it better than SpacePort? I think it is. Is formerly free content now locked away behind a paywall? No. Just look at iTunes and realize how much worse things could be.

That's it for now, there's a flag waiting to be planted on Minmus.
Nope. I knew it wasn't a good idea posting stuff about Curseport. It's controversial after all, and this thread might just degenerate into another anti-Curse battleground. Don't play with fire.

Amazingly, people still buy music from such things as iTunes.

-snip- Space Port was fine and dandy, few problems, no real big ones that break it. Why'd you guys switch? And why Curse? Why not use KerbalStuff if you can't handle spaceport anymore.

Also, could you cite all this information? I don't believe Curse has been better than space port. Especially since the Curse layout is covered in ad's and ad space, obscuring every inch of the background.

Curse is literally an Advertising site for Ads, with the forums and mod's just there to get traffic.

Edited August 7, 2014 by KasperVld
Kerbal Engineer Redux.

-snip- SQUAD wanted to get out of the mod-hosting business (and all the headaches that go with, including bandwidth costs), and went looking for someone to take it off their hands.

Of course people are going to want them to keep hosting mods, for free, as a "community service", but is that really reasonable?

Edited August 7, 2014 by KasperVld

SQUAD wanted to get out of the mod-hosting business (and all the headaches that go with, including bandwidth costs), and went looking for someone to take it off their hands.

This. It's a good move. It means Squad can focus on what they do best, improving KSP. Curse has it's issues, the spaceport had it's issues. Pretty sure any community based repository has its issues. But this move means that Squad needs to spend less time&focus on those issues.
Well said.... Keep going Kerbalstuff, keep going...
